p.s: A 56-year-old patient was brought to our emergency department with profound weakness of his limbs to the point that he was unable to get up from a couch unassisted.
A day earlier, he had been discharged from a neurology service where he had been because of similar complaints.
An 8-day workup including computed tomography and magnetic resonance imaging of the head and spinal column, blood work, and lumbar puncture had not proved helpful.
An electromyogram disclosed changes consistent with sensory motor demyelinizing polyneuropathy.
A nutritional cause for the symptoms was presumed, and with thiamine administration and 8 days of hospital food, there was some improvement.
Serum electrolyte levels were not evaluated.
His medical history disclosed chronic alcohol abuse and degenerative joint disease.
The patient had been advised to start treatment for hypertension but chose not to do so.
The blood pressure measurement was 102/66 mm Hg with a heart rate of 76 beats per minute.
The oxygen saturation by pulse oximetry was 97%.
On examination, the patient was awake, oriented, had normal cranial nerve function, and no sensory defects.
He had profound weakness of upper and lower extremities.
Heart, lungs, and abdomen were unremarkable.
There was substantial pedal edema.
The Diagnosis j Alcohol-associated tubular dysfunction Further workup showed a normal hemogram but revealed profound hypokalemia of 1.5 mmol/l.
Additional laboratory values are listed in Table 1.
The patient was transferred to the intensive care unit, where potassium chloride was given parenterally.

Although the serum potassium level was 1.8 mmol/l, a 12-lead electrocardiogram disclosed T-wave and axis changes of a nonspecific nature, with a suggestion of a U wave providing an additional clue to the clinical problem.
Blood gas analysis showed that arterial pH was 7.39, PaO 2 was 92 mm Hg, and PaCO 2 was 24 mm Hg.
By this time, the sodium level was 137 mmol/l, the potassium level was 3.6 mmol/l, the chloride level was 115 mmol/l, and the bicarbonate level was 14 mmol/l.
Thus, we were dealing with a non-anion-gap metabolic acidosis and respiratory alkalosis.
The urine pH remained at 7.0 during the entire hospital stay.
The renin concentration was 13.4 ng/l and the aldosterone level was <37 ng/l.
The sodium reabsorption was appropriate; however, the tubular absorption of phosphorus was 61% (despite hypophosphatemia).
We concluded that the high urinary potassium excretion (Table 1) could not be attributed to aldosterone. 1 Proximal tubular function was probably also not totally in order.
Our patient had hypophosphatemia and low magnesium values.
We were not in a position to evaluate these matters in detail. 2,3
We performed ultrasonography, which disclosed normal kidneys but evidence of hepatic fibrosis.
Echocardiography established marked diastolic dysfunction.
The ability to determine oxygen saturation has led to an unfortunate decrease in blood gas analyses.
Thus, acid-base disturbances are frequently unrecognized.
This is of particular importance in patients with hypokalemia in whom this test provides important information regarding the cause of the potassium disorder.
Most patients with hypokalemia and alcoholism will have metabolic alkalosis with volume contraction after vomiting.
In contrast, our patient had hypokalemia with distal renal tubular acidosis.
De Marchi et al. 3 described renal tubular dysfunction in chronic alcohol abuse with subsequent improvement after abstinence.
They reported a wide range of defects in renal tubular function, with a normal glomerular filtration rate.
The defects included decreases in the threshold and maximal reabsorptive ability for glucose and in the renal threshold for phosphate excretion in a third of their patients.
They also reported increases in the fractional excretion of b 2 -microglobulin, uric acid, calcium, and magnesium.
Interestingly one quarter of their patients had a defect in tubular acidification, and a few exhibited impaired urinary concentrating ability.

In the face of metabolic acidosis and a urinary pH of 7.0, our patient excreted sodium at 76 mmol/l, potassium at 30 mmol/l, and chloride at 64 mmol/l, suggesting that ammonium excretion was suboptimal (positive urinary anion gap).
His phosphate reabsorption was 61% during hypophosphatemia, suggesting proximal tubular dysfunction.
We initiated potassium substitution with 120 mmol potassium citrate daily.
We also began ramipril 10 mg/d and spironolactone 25 mg 3 times daily.
The patient dropped 10 kg of weight and the edema disappeared.
At discharge, the sodium level was 138 mmol/l, the potassium level was 3.6 mmol/l, the chloride level was 99 mmol/l, and the bicarbonate level was 23 mmol/l.
Motor strength was greatly improved.
The abnormalities of blood chemistry values and renal tubular function improved after 4 weeks of abstinence.
